text: just tell me a little bit how you can't
actually get this interview well it was
extremely difficult Matthew it took us
about three months to arrange it I never

that's not possible given that he's in

surveillance by the FSB so I dealt with
his people via intermediaries and on
some occasions using encrypted
communications for security purposes and
as I mentioned in the little clip there
in the end he agreed to do it it was
very difficult to persuade him because
he basically doesn't trust the British
media except of course the Guardian who
around his story extensively and we were
told to go to Moscow on it on a set date
to book into a hotel provide a room
number and we were told that at a set
time there'll be a knock on the door and
mr. Snowden would appear and my enormous
relief he did so that is what happened
tell me more about that the content we
heard a little bit there the the ability
it is staggering is this notion that
smartphones can be accessed can be
turned on as you carry them and then
listened in that did surprise me I mean
you know you read spy novels and
thrillers and you assume they have these
tremendous capabilities to find out
everything that you're doing
the reality is that they do and I'd
always assumed that you know we all
assumed that you know our phones are
tapped but what I didn't know until
Edward Snowden talked about him is based
on a document that he leaked from GCHQ a
training document about the capabilities
using the Smurfs cartoon characters to

was the ability of GCHQ to actually turn

phone without you knowing it and as a

it there's a difference here between

that is there
and it's just any smartphone that they

you know your smartphone or my

wrong if people gets the I get the idea
that their phones are being monitored
every day by GCHQ they're not tell me
little more about the hacking of large

Pakistan how they went about doing that
that did surprise me that did surprise
me it didn't surprise me because that
data obviously helps them identify and
track terrorists in Pakistan in
Waziristan or wherever they are
but what GCHQ did with authorization
from the government from the Foreign
Office is they hacked into the Reuters
that carry the traffic coming out of
Pakistan and diverted all that material
to GCHQ in in the UK Cisco the huge
American company that makes the reuters
did not know about it and it wasn't just
the pakistani reuters but other reuters
which have been you know taken over by
GCHQ and the NSA their American
counterpart and and they were so
concerned that they brought me the chief

to President Obama it was that serious
just a twin final thought because who
saw in that clip no regrets no
acknowledgement and what the security
services say the enormous damage he
created with with his leak was that
total there was not even a glimmer of
insight as to what the concern is from
him in all of your conversations what
does he think is actually going to
happen to him as well well first of all
he doesn't accept that he's caused the
damage that the intelligence agencies
say he's caused I mean there's no doubt
he has caused damage but also he
believes and a lot of people would agree
he's done the service in raising these
issues for us and making us aware of the
capabilities that the agencies have with
regard to his future his face is between
a rock and a hard place he may be doomed
to stay in Russia forever or he may go
back to America which is what he wants
to do and stand trial and face a jail
sentence how
he's being charged under the Espionage

as a spy which he says he's not and he's
not a spy
but as a whistleblower that might
produce a reduced sentence but this is
